questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with weakness in his right hand and difficulty extending his fingers and wrist. Physical examination reveals intact sensation but significant weakness in wrist and finger extension on the affected side. He recently had a fall and sustained a forearm injury. Which of the following muscles is most likely affected in this patient's condition, and which nerve is responsible for its innervation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Extensor Digitorum

 

Option D:

 

  • Among given option only Extensor digitorum is muscle of posterior compartment of forearm.
  • Posterior compartment of forearm muscles are supplied by Radial nerve or its deep branch (PIN)
  • Deep branch of radial nerve is known as Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN)
  • Radial nerve & its different branches shown in image

 

 

  • From image it is clear that PIN supplies all muscles of posterior compartment of forearm except 3 muscles (ABE):
    • A-  Anconeus
    • B-  Brachioradialis
    • E-  ECRL

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Flexor digitorum superficialis is innervated by the median nerve.

 

Option B. Pronator quadratus is innervated by the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve.

 

Option C. Brachioradialis is innervated by the radial nerve before termination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extensor digitorum in the posterior compartment of the forearm is innervated by the posterior interosseous nerve.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 101

questions.text: A 45-year-old office worker complains of persistent wrist pain and difficulty performing repetitive tasks on a computer keyboard. Physical examination reveals tenderness at the wrist joint and decreased range of motion, particularly during wrist flexion and extension. Radiographic evaluation shows evidence of degenerative changes in the joint space. Which of the following bones is NOT directly involved in the formation of the wrist joint?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ulna

 

Option B:

 

  • In this question the examiner is trying to ask bone forming the wrist bone. Bones which participate in formation of wrist joint include - Radius, Scaphoid, Lunate, Triquetral
  • Ulna does not contribute to the wrist joint formation.
  • An articular disc separates the ulna from cavity of wrist joint as shown in image:

 

 

  • The carpus / wrist is formed by 8 carpal bones.
  • These are arranged in two rows. (Mnemonic : “She Looks Too Pretty, Try To Catch Her”)

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Scaphoid takes part in the formation of wrist joint.

 

Option C. Lower end of radius participates in the formation of wrist joint.

 

Option D. Triquetral also participates in the formation of wrist joint.

 

Educational objective:

 

Wrist joint is an ellipsoid joint formed by articulation between lower end of radius and scaphoid, lunate and triquetral.

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 153

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents to the clinic with weakness in the thumb and difficulty gripping objects. On examination, the patient exhibits a loss of opposition of the thumb, as well as atrophy of the thenar eminence. Which of the following muscles is primarily supplied by the median nerve and is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Flexor Pollicis Brevis

 

Option D:

 

  • In this case thumb/thenar muscles are involved which are supplied by median nerve (except Grave yard of ulnar nerve i.e.- adductor pollicis which is supplied by ulnar nerve.)
  • Among given options only Flexor pollicis brevis is thenar muscle hence it is the answer.
  • 4 Thenar Muscles shown in image:

 

 

  • 4 Hypothenar Muscles shown in image:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Palmaris brevis is innervated by the superficial branch of the ulnar nerve.

 

Option B. All dorsal interossei are innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve.

 

Option C. Extensor pollicis longus is innervated by the posterior interosseous nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flexor pollicis brevis, Opponens pollicis, Abductor pollicis brevis, first and second lumbricals in the hand are innervated by the median nerve.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 166

questions.text: In the given image the nerve injured is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Left Hypoglossal Nerve

 

Option D:

 

The given image shows deviation of tip of tongue to left side on protrusion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Right Lingual nerve is purely sensory to the tongue and arises from posterior division of mandibular division of trigeminal nerve

 

Option B. Left Lingual nerve carries general sensation from anterior 2/3 tongue

 

Option C. Hypoglossal nerve innervates all muscles of tongue except palatoglossus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hypoglossal nerve injury the tip of the protruded tongue deviates to the paralysed side.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 148

questions.text: Which of the following speech disorders is caused by the injury of the structure shown in the histological image?
questions.solution:
Ans: C) Dysarthria

 

Option C:

 

  • Given image is the Histological slide of cerebellum.
  • Lesion of neocerebellum leads to dysarthria or scanning speech which is slurred, prolonged, explosive and with pauses in wrong places.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Apraxia is inability to perform motor activities in the presence of intact motor and sensory systems and normal comprehension. Ideomotor apraxia, Ideational apraxia seen in lesion of sensory speech area. Constructional apraxia is due to lesion of inferior parietal lobule

 

Option B: Aphasia is impaired/absent communication by speech, writing, signs due to lesion in dominant hemisphere. Eg motor aphasia, sensory aphasia, conduction aphasia, global aphasia, thalamic aphasia

 

Option D: Dysprosody is Non dominant hemispheric language deficits that affect the emotionality of speech

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dysarthria is a motor speech disorder resulting from neurological injury of the motor component of the motor-speech system. It is characterized by poor articulation of phonemes, which means the clarity of speech is affected. While it does not initiate speech, it coordinates the timing and force of muscle movements required for smooth, clear, and rapid speech.
  • Cerebellar Dysarthria: When the cerebellum is damaged, it can lead to a specific type of dysarthria, often characterized by the following:
    • Slurred Speech: Speech may be slurred and sound 'drunken'.
    • Irregular Speech Rhythm and Rate: Speech may be excessively slow or fast, and the rhythm may be irregular.
    • Variable Tone: The voice might have a monotonous tone or fluctuate excessively.
    • Difficulty with Coordination of Speech Movements: There may be problems with the coordination of lip, tongue, and jaw movements, affecting articulation.
    • Volume Control Issues: The speech might be unusually loud or soft.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Clinical Neuroanatomy, 2nd edition pg 150-151

questions.text: Which of the following features are seen by the lesion of the marked structure in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans: D) Contralateral Hemiplegia

 

Option D:

 

  • Marked structure is a pyramid on the ventral surface of medulla just lateral to anterior median fissure.
  • The corticospinal fibres lie underneath the pyramid. Lesion of which will cause contralateral hemiplegia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ataxia refers to a lack of muscle coordination that can affect speech, eye movements, the ability to swallow, walking, and other voluntary movements. It is commonly associated with lesions in the cerebellum or in the sensory pathways.

 

Option B. Vertigo is a sense of spinning or dizziness, often related to problems in the inner ear or vestibular system. Lesions in the vestibular nuclei in the brainstem, the vestibulocochlear nerve, or the inner ear can lead to vertigo.

 

Option C. Ipsilateral Facial Nerve Palsy refers to weakness or paralysis of the facial muscles on the same side as the lesion. It is commonly associated with lesions affecting the facial nerve (Cranial Nerve VII), which could be at the level of the brainstem or the nerve itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Contralateral Hemiplegia:  This is paralysis on the side of the body opposite to the side of the brain where the lesion is located.
  • Lesions in the motor pathways, especially in the cerebral cortex or internal capsule, can lead to contralateral hemiplegia because motor fibers decussate (cross over) in the medulla.
  • When considering neurological symptoms such as ataxia, vertigo, facial nerve palsy, and hemiplegia, it is essential to identify the location of the lesion in the brain, as the symptoms can provide key insights into the affected area.
  • Ataxia typically indicates cerebellar or sensory pathway lesions, vertigo suggests vestibular system involvement, ipsilateral facial nerve palsy points to facial nerve or brainstem involvement, and contralateral hemiplegia is indicative of motor pathway lesions, often in the cerebral cortex or internal capsule.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Clinical Neuroanatomy, 2nd edition pg 73-75

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C- Projection fibre

 

Marked structures in the given image are:

 

Option A: A - Forceps minor of Corpus callosum is the largest commissural fibre. Fibres passing through the body connect most of the frontal and anterior part of the parietal lobe of the two hemispheres

 

Option B: B - Genu of internal capsule is traversed by frontopontine fibres, corticonuclear and corticospinal fibres for head and neck, anterior part of superior thalamic radiation. Internal capsule is projection fibre

 

Option C: C - Body of fornix. Fornix is large bundle of projection fibre that connects hippocampus with mammillary body

 

Option D: D - Forceps major. Fibres of the splenium connect the posterior part of parietal lobe, temporal and occipital lobe of both the hemispheres. Corpus callosum is the type of associational fibers.

 

Explanation:

 

  • Projection Fibers: Projection fibers in the brain are axons that project out of the brain to the spinal cord, or from the spinal cord to the brain. They are involved in transmitting sensory and motor information between the brain and the rest of the body. The most well-known projection fibers are the corticospinal tract and the spinothalamic tract.
  • Association Fibers: Association fibers are axons that connect different parts of the same cerebral hemisphere. They play a crucial role in integrating information within a single hemisphere. The arcuate fasciculus, which connects Wernicke's and Broca's areas, is a classic example of an association fiber.
  • If A and C represent tracts that connect different regions of the brain to the body or vice versa, they would be projection fibers.
  • If B and D represent tracts that connect different areas within the same cerebral hemisphere, they would be association fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of brain white matter tracts as either projection fibers (connecting the brain to the body and vice versa) or association fibers (connecting different regions within the same hemisphere) is crucial for understanding the organization and functional connectivity of the brain.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Clinical Neuroanatomy, 2nd edition pg 164, 168, 232

choices.text: Contralateral loss of pain & temperature in trunk and limbs
Contralateral loss of position and vibration sense
Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation from face
Ipsilateral paralysis of muscles of palate

questions.text: MRI of 60-year-old female reveals a defect in the territory served by the artery marked in given MRA. Which of the following features is not a component of the syndrome related to the vessel indicated by the yellow arrows:
questions.solution:
Ans: B) Contralateral loss of position and vibration sense

 

Option B:

 

  • Marked structure in the given MRA is Posterior inferior cerebellar artery which is a tortuous branch from vertebral artery.
  • It supplies the posterolateral zone of medulla.
  • Occlusion of which will lead to Lateral medullary syndrome/Wallenberg syndrome.
  • Contralateral loss of position and vibration sense is due to damage to medial lemniscus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Contralateral Loss of Pain & Temperature in Trunk and Limbs is a classic feature of Lateral Medullary Syndrome. The lesion affects the spinothalamic tract in the medulla, which carries pain and temperature sensations. Since these fibers decussate (cross over) at the level of the spinal cord, the deficit is observed on the side opposite the lesion.

 

Option C. Ipsilateral Loss of Pain and Temperature Sensation from Face is consistent with Lateral Medullary Syndrome. The lesion affects the ascending tract and nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, leading to loss of pain and temperature sensation on the same side of the face as the lesion.

 

Option D. Ipsilateral Paralysis of Muscles of Palate is also a feature of Lateral Medullary Syndrome. The lesion can affect the nucleus ambiguus, resulting in ipsilateral paralysis of the palate, pharynx, and larynx, leading to dysphagia, hoarseness, and possibly a deviation of the uvula away from the side of the lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contralateral Loss of Position and Vibration Sense:

 

  • This is NOT typically seen in Lateral Medullary Syndrome. The medial lemniscus, which carries proprioception and vibration sense, is usually spared in PICA territory lesions as it is located more medially in the brainstem and is supplied by other arteries.
  • In the context of Lateral Medullary Syndrome due to a lesion in the territory of the Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery, expect to find contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body, ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face, and ipsilateral paralysis of the palate, but not contralateral loss of position and vibration sense, which is typically preserved.
  • This is seen in medial medullary syndrome not lateral medullary syndrome

 

Ref:  Vishram Singh Textbook of Clinical Neuroanatomy, 2nd edition, pg 78

questions.text: Which of the following structure projects into which thalamic nucleus?
questions.solution:
Ans: B) Anterior

 

Option B:

 

  • Marked structure is the Mammillary body (mammillary nuclei) in the mammillary region of hypothalamus.
  • The fornix projects from hippocampus to mammillary body.

 

 

  • The mammillothalamic tract carries impulses from the mammillary body to the anterior nucleus of thalamus.
  • The efferent from anterior nucleus of thalamus projected to cingulate gyrus

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The ventrolateral nucleus of the thalamus is involved in motor functions. It receives inputs primarily from the basal ganglia and the cerebellum. The mammillary bodies do not project to the ventrolateral nucleus.

 

Option C. The ventral anterior nucleus of the thalamus is also involved in motor functions. It receives inputs from the basal ganglia and is involved in the initiation and planning of movements. The mammillary bodies do not project to the ventral anterior nucleus.

 

Option D. The ventral posterolateral nucleus is involved in sensory processing, particularly conveying somatosensory information from the body to the sensory cortex. There is no direct projection from the mammillary bodies to the ventral posterolateral nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anterior Nucleus: The anterior nucleus of the thalamus is part of the limbic system and is involved in memory and emotional responses. The mammillary bodies project to the anterior nucleus via the mammillothalamic tract. This connection is a key component of the Papez circuit, which is important in the formation of memory.
  • Understand that the mammillary bodies project to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus, a key part of the Papez circuit involved in memory processing and emotional responses, distinguishing this connection from those involved in motor and sensory functions.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Clinical Neuroanatomy, 2nd edition, pg 130, 232.

choices.text: The median nerve of the right hand is injured.
There is weakness of thenar muscles on the right side
The adductor pollicis of the right side is weak
The flexor muscles of the thumb of the right hand is weak

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents to the orthopedic clinic with complaints of progressive weakness in his right hand. The patient reports difficulty in fine movements of hand. Doctor performed a test over patient as shown in image. Which of the following statements is true about the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The adductor pollicis of the right side is weak

 

Option C:

 

  • Patient is having difficulty in fine movement of the hand which clearly indicates that this question is about the ulnar nerve. Because the ulnar nerve is considered as the nerve which is responsible for fine movements since it supplies 15 out of 20 muscles of the hand.
  • The above image shows Froment’s sign/ Book test/ Adductor Pollicis Test.
  • At thenar eminence the adductor pollicis muscle is supplied by ulnar nerve and the test shown in the image is checking the adductor muscle of thumb (thenar eminence) hence in turn it is checking the ulnar nerve.
  • Due to an injury of the ulnar nerve the patient is unable to adduct his thumb.
  • All the thenar muscles are supplied by the median nerve except adductor pollicis which is supplied by the ulnar nerve.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The median nerve is not injured as the inability to adduct the thumb is due to injury to the ulnar nerve.

 

Option B. The thenar muscles are innervated by the median nerve. Hence no weakness of thenar muscles on the right side will be found because damaged nerve in this case is ulnar nerve.

 

Option D. The flexor pollicis brevis muscles is supplied by the median nerve and flexor pollicis longus is supplied by the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve in the forearm. So, they are not weak on the right side.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The adductor pollicis is innervated by a deep branch of the ulnar nerve and causes adduction of the thumb. The patient is unable to adduct his thumb due to paralysis of adductor pollicis which is supplied by the ulnar nerve. He tries to hold the book by flexing his thumb.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, upper limb and thorax, Vishram Singh, 3rd edition, pg. 131

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-4, B-3, C-5, D-2

 

Correct matching is.

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Subcostal vessels and nerve run along the inferior border of the 12th rib. They are not directly associated with any of the specific diaphragmatic openings but are related to the area just below the ribcage They pass behind the lateral arcuate ligament.
  2. The sympathetic trunk runs vertically along the vertebral column. It is located posteriorly in the abdomen and is not directly associated with the diaphragmatic openings but lies behind the medial arcuate ligament.
  3. Superior epigastric vessels are continuations of the internal thoracic (mammary) artery and vein. They travel through the space of Larrey, which is a gap between the sternal and costal attachments of the diaphragm on either side.
  4. The thoracic duct is the main lymphatic duct of the body. It ascends through the aortic opening of the diaphragm at the level of T12.
  5. The phrenic nerve provides the main motor supply to the diaphragm. The right phrenic nerve enters the thoracic cavity and passes through the caval opening (IVC opening) in the diaphragm at the level of T8.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Minor openings in Diaphragm:

 

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen, Pg. 180

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the clinic with a 3-month history of back pain, weight loss, and jaundice. His past medical history includes Type 2 diabetes mellitus, newly diagnosed four months ago. On examination, he is jaundiced with palpable, nontender gallbladder. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin. An abdominal CT scan is ordered to investigate a suspected pancreatic pathology. If a tumor is present in the uncinate process of the pancreas, which of the following vessels is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Superior Mesenteric Artery

 

Option A:

 

  • The uncinate process is a small hook-like structure that extends from the lower part of the head of the pancreas.

  • It lies posterior to the superior mesenteric vessels. In the case of a tumor in the uncinate process, the Superior Mesenteric Artery (SMA) is the vessel most likely to be involved or compressed.

 

 

 

  • The patient's clinical presentation with new-onset diabetes, back pain, weight loss, jaundice, and a palpable gallbladder (Courvoisier's sign) raises a high suspicion for pancreatic cancer.

  • Involvement of the SMA by a tumor of the uncinate process can lead to a range of symptoms due to the compression of the vessel and can also significantly affect the surgical approach and prognosis of pancreatic cancer.

  •  Understanding these anatomical relationships is essential in the management of pancreatic pathologies.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The portal vein is formed by the confluence of the SMV and the splenic vein. While it is in close proximity to the pancreas, it is not as directly related to the uncinate process as the SMA.

 

Option C. The common hepatic artery supplies blood to the liver and arises from the celiac trunk. It is located more superiorly in relation to the uncinate process. A tumor in the uncinate process is less likely to directly affect the common hepatic artery compared to the SMA.

 

Option D. The Inferior Mesenteric Artery (IMA) supplies the lower part of the large intestine. It is located quite distant from the uncinate process and is unlikely to be affected by a tumor in this part of the pancreas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The uncinate process of the pancreas lies posterior to the Superior mesenteric artery and the superior mesenteric vein.

  • A tumor in the uncinate process can potentially compress or involve the SMA, leading to vascular complications or challenges during surgical resection.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen, Pg. 128

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman pregnant with her first child had been in the second stage of labor (pushing) for several hours. The crown of the child’s head was just visible through the vaginal orifice, but the obstetrician was concerned that the woman was exhausted and was no longer able to push effectively. She decided to perform an episiotomy to enlarge the opening of the birth canal and assist the delivery of the baby. If a midline episiotomy incision were to continue tearing, all the following structures could be damaged except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urethra

 

Option C: Urethra forms the anterior relation and is infrequently involved.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The perineal body is a fibromuscular mass located between the vaginal orifice and the anus. It is an important structure for the integrity of the perineum and is at risk of damage if a midline episiotomy extends. Damage to the perineal body can lead to weakness of the pelvic floor and associated complications. If the incision tears further during the delivery, a median incision is more likely than a posterolateral incision to extend posteriorly through the perineal body, the external anal sphincter, the internal anal sphincter, and the rectum.

 

 

Option B. In cases where a midline episiotomy extends or tears further, it can potentially involve the anterior wall of the rectum. This is particularly concerning as it can lead to complications like rectovaginal fistula. Serious tears may become infected by bowel contents, as may the child as it passes through the birth canal. This may delay or impair adequate healing for the mother or even present significant health risks (i.e. septicemia) for mother or child.

 

Option D. The external anal sphincter is at risk of damage if a midline episiotomy tears further. This can lead to issues with fecal incontinence if the sphincter is significantly damaged. External anal sphincter forms the posterior relation of vagina, if torn in episiotomy can later lead to faecal incontinence. The integrity of the perineal body is critical to the strength of the entire perineum in women. Unrepaired injury can cause dysfunction of the external anal sphincter, internal anal sphincter, and/or sexual dysfunction (e.g., dyspareunia).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The urethra, located anteriorly to the vaginal orifice, is generally not at risk of damage from a midline episiotomy. Midline episiotomies are made posteriorly and are aimed towards the perineum and anus. Therefore, the urethra is typically safe from damage in this scenario.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh, Textbook of Anatomy, 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen, Pg. 225

questions.text: Fertilisation occurs in which part of the Fallopian Tube?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ampulla

 

Option A: Fertilization, the process where the sperm meets and fuses with an ovum (egg), typically occurs in the fallopian tubes in females. Fertilization of ovum takes place in ampulla, it is thin walled, dilated and tortuous.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The isthmus is the narrowest part of the fallopian tube, located between the ampulla and the uterine part of the tube. While sperm can pass through this area, it is less commonly the site of fertilization compared to the ampulla.

 

Option C. Interstitial of the fallopian tube is the part that passes through the uterine wall. It connects the fallopian tube to the uterine cavity. Fertilization does not typically occur in this segment.

 

Option D. The infundibulum is the funnel-shaped end of the fallopian tube near the ovary. It has finger-like projections called fimbriae, which help in capturing the released ovum from the ovary. While the infundibulum plays a crucial role in egg capture, it is not the primary site of fertilization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ampulla is the widest section of the fallopian tube and is the usual site of fertilization. It is located between the infundibulum and the isthmus. The ampulla provides an ideal environment for the sperm to meet the ovum, and fertilization usually occurs here.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh, Textbook of Anatomy, 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen, Pg. 257

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about Levator Ani Muscle function and support:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Attached to Pelvic Brim.

 

Option D: Levator ani arises from the sides of the walls of the pelvis along the condensation of obturator fascia (the tendinous arch of levator ani).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The levator ani muscle group plays a crucial role in supporting the pelvic viscera, including the bladder, intestines, and uterus in females. It forms a major part of the pelvic floor and helps maintain pelvic organ position and function. Levator ani supports pelvic viscera and counteracts downward thrust of diaphragm during increased intra-abdominal pressure.

 

Option B. The fibers of the levator ani muscles converge towards the midline and move downwards. This orientation is important for their role in supporting the pelvic organs and maintaining continence.

 

Option C. The levator ani muscle is comprised of a few parts, with the iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus being two of them. Levator ani and coccygeus together form pelvic diaphragm. The puborectalis is another component of this muscle group. Each part has a specific role in pelvic floor function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The levator ani muscles are not attached to the pelvic brim. Instead, they originate from the inner surface of the pelvis, specifically from the pelvic sidewalls and areas such as the pubis and ischial spine. The pelvic brim is the edge of the pelvic inlet, which is higher up and not the point of attachment for these muscles.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh, Textbook of Anatomy, 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen, Pg. 207

questions.text: Secondary support of the Uterus is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Broad Ligament

 

Option D: The support of the uterus is typically divided into primary and secondary supports. Broad ligament is a broad fold of peritoneum that consists of two layers and extends from the lateral border of the uterus to the lateral pelvic wall.

 

Primary supports are the true ligaments and secondary supports are the folds of peritoneum which help in keeping the uterus in place.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mackenrodt Ligament, Also known as the cardinal ligament, is a primary support of the uterus. It extends from the cervix to the lateral walls of the pelvis and is one of the key structures in maintaining the position of the uterus.

 

Option B. The uterosacral ligament is also considered a primary support of the uterus. It extends from the cervix to the sacrum and helps to maintain the uterus in its normal anteverted position.

 

Option C. The round ligament of the uterus runs from the uterine horns through the inguinal canal to the labia majora. It is considered a secondary support of the uterus. The round ligament plays a role in maintaining the anteverted position of the uterus but is not as significant in terms of overall support as the primary ligaments like the cardinal or uterosacral ligaments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The broad ligament is a double layer of peritoneum that extends from the sides of the uterus to the lateral walls and floor of the pelvis. It encloses the fallopian tubes, ovaries, and related structures. While the broad ligament is associated with the uterus, it is not considered a significant structural support. since it is fold of peritoneum and not a true ligament. It is more of a mesentery that provides a pathway for blood vessels and nerves to the uterus and other pelvic structures.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen, Pg. 273

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a bulge and discomfort in her lower abdomen. She reports a sensation of something protruding in the area. During the physical examination, the physician suspects an issue related to the inguinal canal. Which of the following structures typically does NOT pass through the inguinal canal in females and may not contribute to the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inferior Epigastric Artery

 

Option D:

 

  • The Inferior Epigastric Artery arises from the External Iliac Artery immediately Superior to the Inguinal Ligament.
  • It ascends medially to the deep inguinal ring towards the midline while running posterior to the spermatic cord and anterior to the transversalis fascia.

 

 

  • Below the arcuate line, the inferior epigastric vessels pierce the transversalis fascia on each side of the rectus sheath and enter the rectus abdominis muscle.
  • The inguinal canal is a passage in the lower abdominal wall that allows certain structures to pass between the abdomen and the groin.
  • In females, the structures that typically pass through the inguinal canal include the ilioinguinal nerve, the round ligament of the uterus, and lymphatics from the uterus.
  • These structures can sometimes be associated with conditions like inguinal hernias. However, the inferior epigastric artery does not normally pass through the inguinal canal in females. Therefore, issues related to this artery would not be directly associated with inguinal canal-related symptoms in females.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The ilioinguinal nerve does pass through the inguinal canal. It is a branch of the first lumbar nerve (L1) and provides sensory innervation to the skin of the lower part of the abdomen, upper medial thigh, and external genitalia.

 

Option B. The round ligament of the uterus indeed passes through the inguinal canal in females. It is a structure that extends from the uterine horns, passes through the inguinal canal, and ends in the labia majora.

 

Option C. Lymphatic vessels from the uterus do pass through the inguinal canal. These lymphatics are particularly involved in the lymphatic drainage of the lower part of the uterus and are important in the context of the spread of certain types of uterine cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The inferior epigastric artery does not pass through the inguinal canal. It arises from the external iliac artery just above the inguinal ligament and ascends along the posterior surface of the rectus abdominis muscle. It is located in the abdominal wall and is not a content of the inguinal canal.

 

 

Ref: Vishram Singh, Textbook of Anatomy, 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen, Pg. 48

questions.text: Identify the nerve whose injury causes lateral gaze palsy:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

Option C:

 

  • Abducens nerve supplies lateral rectus muscle, injury to which cause lateral gaze palsy.

  • Abducens nerve lies in the floor of cavernous sinus lateral to internal carotid artery.

 

The marked structure in the given image are:

 

  1. Oculomotor Nerve

  2. Trochlear Nerve

  3. Abducens Nerve

  4. Ophthalmic division of Trigeminal Nerve

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Oculomotor nerve lies in the lateral wall of cavernous sinus. It enters the orbit as upper and division through intermediate compartment of superior orbital fissure.

 

Option B. Trochlear nerve lies in the lateral wall of cavernous sinus. It enters the orbit through lateral compartment of superior orbital fissure.

 

Option D. Ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve lies in the lateral wall of cavernous sinus. It divides into lacrimal, frontal and nasociliary branches.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Abducens nerve supplies lateral rectus muscle, injury to which cause lateral gaze palsy.

  • Abducens nerve lies in the floor of cavernous sinus lateral to internal carotid artery.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg. 377

choices.text: The scaphoid is the largest carpal bone
Trapezium is the largest carpal bone
Pisiform bone is not seen in this x-ray
Lunate is the smallest carpal bone

questions.text: An eight-year-old male child managed to take his board game from the loft after standing on top of two chairs one over the other. But while trying to get down, he fell down from the topmost and experienced severe pain over his right hand, back & leg. The image given is his x-ray. Which of the following statements is true pertaining to the given case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pisiform bone is not seen in this x-ray

 

Option C:

 

  • Pisiform is sesamoid bone, smallest carpal bone & last carpal bone to ossify.
  • It ossify between 9 to 12 years of age.
  • Since the age of child is 8 years hence it is not ossified & not visible in X ray.

 

Ossification of carpal bones are shown in sequence in image below:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The scaphoid is not the largest carpal bone; capitate is the largest carpal bone.

 

Option B. Trapezium is also not the the largest carpal bone.

 

Option D. Pisiform is the smallest carpal bone, not the Lunate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pisiform bone is the: 
    • Smallest Bone
    • Last Bone to ossify (12th year)
    • Sesamoid Bone (within the tendon of flexor carpi ulnaris)
    • Capitate is the largest of carpal bones and starts ossification first.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 29

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a painful swelling in his right groin area. On physical examination, a bulge is noted at the mid inguinal point, which is located midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis. This finding is most suggestive of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Indirect Inguinal Hernia

 

Option B: Indirect Inguinal Hernia is the most common type of hernia in both men and women. It protrudes at the mid inguinal point, which is a landmark used to distinguish between direct and indirect inguinal hernias.

 

The indirect inguinal hernia lies lateral to inferior epigastric vessels hence the bulging is seen at the level of midinguinal point.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Femoral Hernia: Typically appears below the inguinal ligament, more common in women. The location described in the question does not correspond to the typical site of a femoral hernia.

 

Option C. Direct Inguinal Hernia: Occurs medially to the inferior epigastric vessels and typically presents in older men. It protrudes through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, which is not at the mid inguinal point.

 

Option D. Spigelian Hernia: Occurs along the spigelian fascia, which is found lateral to the rectus abdominis muscles. This is not consistent with the location described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Indirect Inguinal Hernia is the most common type of hernia in both men and women. It protrudes at the mid inguinal point, which is a landmark used to distinguish between direct and indirect inguinal hernias.
  • This type of hernia follows the path of the inguinal canal and often protrudes into the scrotum in men.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Abdomen and Lower Limb, 3rd Edition, Vishram Singh, Volume II, pg. 55

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to the orthopedic clinic with a history of shoulder pain and limited range of motion. The physician suspects rotator cuff pathology and discusses the relevant muscles during the examination. Which of the following muscles is NOT considered part of the rotator cuff group and is not typically associated with rotator cuff injuries?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Teres Major

 

Option C:

 

  • Teres major is inserted into medial lip of inter tubercular sulcus which is away from position of rotator cuff. That’s why teres major is not the rotator cuff muscle.

 

 

  • There are 4 rotator cuff muscles (Mnemonic SItS)
    • S- Supra spinatous
    • I- Infra spinatous
    • t- teres minor (Not the Teres major)
    • S- Subscapularis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Subscapularis is innervated by upper and lower subscapular nerves.

 

Option B. Supraspinatus and infraspinatus are innervated by suprascapular nerve.

 

Option D. Teres minor is innervated by the axillary nerve. Teres major is innervated by lower subscapular nerve.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Subscapularis, supraspinatus, infraspinatus and teres minor form the rotator cuff muscles.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 73

questions.text: Which nerve supplies the marked structure in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lower division of III Nerve

 

Option C:

 

  • Pointed structure is medial rectus muscle.

  • The medial rectus muscle, which is one of the extraocular muscles responsible for eye movement, is indeed supplied by the lower division of the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) innervates the superior oblique muscle, not the medial rectus. The superior oblique muscle turns the eye downward and laterally.

 

Option B. The upper division of the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) innervates the superior rectus and levator palpebrae superioris muscles. The superior rectus muscle elevates the eye, while the levator palpebrae superioris raises the upper eyelid.

 

Option D. The abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye (moves it laterally, away from the nose).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Medial rectus muscle lies in the medial wall of orbit below the superior oblique muscle.  It is innervated by Lower division of III nerve.

  • Lower Division of III Nerve: The lower division of the oculomotor nerve innervates the medial rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles. The medial rectus muscle moves the eye medially (towards the nose).

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 256

questions.text: Where does the Hassal’s corpuscle is present??
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thymus

 

Option A:

 

  • Hassall’s corpuscle is present in medulla of thymus.


​​​​​​

Explanation:

 

Option B. Spleen contains white pulp and red pulp, but it does not contain Hassall's corpuscles. Spleen has white pulp which consists of lymphoid follicles with eccentrically placed arteriole. Hassall's corpuscles are specific to the thymus gland.

 

Option C. Lymph nodes are small, bean-shaped structures that are part of the lymphatic system. It has cortex with lymphoid follicles, paracortex with T lymphocytes, medulla. While lymph nodes contain follicles and germinal centers important for immune function, they do not have Hassall's corpuscles, which are unique to the thymus.

 

Option D. Appendix has lymphoid follicles in lamina propria and submucous. However, it does not contain Hassall's corpuscles. These structures are specifically associated with the thymus gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hassall's corpuscles are distinctive structures found in the thymus gland.

  • They are composed of concentrically arranged epithelial cells and are characteristic of the medulla of the thymus.

  • Hassall's corpuscles are thought to play a role in the maturation of T cells and in the induction of tolerance in the immune system.

 

Ref: Histology, Text and Atlas Brijesh Kumar Page No.  142

questions.text: In which of the following structure, sinusoids not typically seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kidney

 

Option B:

 

  • Kidney has cortex with renal corpuscles, PCT, DCT and medulla with loop of henle, collecting ducts



 

  • Sinusoids are a type of capillary found in certain organs.

  • They are characterized by their large diameter and discontinuous, fenestrated endothelium.

  • Sinusoids are commonly found in the liver, spleen, and lymph nodes, where they play a role in filtering blood and lymph.

  • In contrast, the kidney, which is primarily involved in filtration and excretion of waste products, does not contain sinusoids. Instead, it has a specialized structure of capillaries known as glomeruli, which are essential for its filtering function.

  • The patient's presentation of hematuria and kidney dysfunction would not be directly related to the presence of sinusoids, as they are not a typical feature of renal histology.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sinusoids are a key feature of the liver. Liver sinusoids are unique blood vessels that differ from capillaries due to their larger size, irregular shape, and fenestrated endothelium. These sinusoids facilitate the exchange of materials between the blood and liver cells.

 

Option C. Lymph nodes contain sinusoids, known as lymphatic sinusoids or lymph sinuses. These are channels within the lymph node that allow lymph to flow through the node, where it is filtered. Lymph sinuses are lined by endothelial cells and are crucial for the immune function of lymph nodes.

 

Option D. The spleen also contains sinusoids, known as splenic sinusoids or sinusoidal capillaries. These are part of the red pulp of the spleen and are involved in filtering blood, removing old or damaged red blood cells, and recycling iron. The unique structure of splenic sinusoids facilitates the spleen's role in blood filtration.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The kidney does not contain sinusoids. Instead, it has a specialized structure of blood vessels, including glomeruli and a series of arterioles and capillaries, which are essential for the kidney's function in filtering blood and forming urine.

  • Renal circulation is specialized for the process of ultrafiltration and does not involve sinusoids.

 

Ref: Histology, Text and Atlas Brijesh Kumar Page No. 234

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a history alcohol abuse presents to your clinic complaining of fatigue and abdominal discomfort. In which organ are the stellate cells of von Kupffer, located in the sinusoids and involved in the immune response, typically found?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Liver

 

Option B:

 

  • Hepatic sinusoids in liver are lined by phagocytic cells called kupffer cells.



 

  • Stellate cells of von Kupffer are specialized macrophages found in the liver, specifically within the sinusoids.

  • These cells play a critical role in the liver's immune response, including phagocytosis of bacteria and debris, and they are also involved in liver fibrosis.

  • The patient's history of alcohol abuse, along with his clinical presentation suggest liver pathology.

  • The stellate cells of von Kupffer, being integral to the liver's immune and fibrotic responses, are key cellular components in the context of his liver disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Spleen contains sinusoids, known as splenic sinusoids, and various immune cells. Splenic sinusoids are lined by tall barrel shaped cells called stave cells.

 

Option C. Bone Marrow has a rich vascular network, it does not contain Kupffer cells. The stellate cells of von Kupffer are unique to the liver.

 

Option D. Adrenal do not contain Kupffer cells. The structure and cell types of the adrenal glands are geared towards hormone production and secretion, not the filtration functions of Kupffer cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The stellate cells of von Kupffer, also known as Kupffer cells, are found in the liver.

  • Space of Disse in liver is perisinusoidal between endothelial cells lining hepatic sinusoids and hepatocytes.

  • They are a type of macrophage located in the liver sinusoids and are responsible for phagocytosing bacteria, old red blood cells, and other debris in the blood. Kupffer cells play a crucial role in liver function and the body's immune defense.

 

Ref: Histology, Text and Atlas Brijesh Kumar Page No. 207

questions.text: All are branches of Inferior Mesenteric Artery except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Middle Rectal

 

Option C:

 

  • The inferior mesenteric artery is a major artery in the abdomen that supplies blood to the large intestine. Middle rectal artery arises from anterior division of internal iliac artery passes within lateral ligaments of rectum to supply lower third of rectum.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Left colic artery arises from inferior mesenteric artery and divides into ascending and descending branch. It supplies the descending colon and part of the transverse colon.

 

Option B. Sigmoidal arteries are two to three in number, arise from inferior mesenteric arteries. The sigmoidal arteries, also known as sigmoid arteries, are branches of the inferior mesenteric artery. They supply the sigmoid colon.

 

Option D. The highest sigmoidal artery anastomoses with a descending branch of the left colic artery and lowest sigmoidal artery with superior rectal artery. The superior rectal artery is the terminal branch of the inferior mesenteric artery. It supplies the upper part of the rectum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The middle rectal artery is typically a branch of the internal iliac artery, not the inferior mesenteric artery. It supplies the rectum, which makes this the correct answer as it is not a branch of the IMA.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy 3rd Edition, Vol II, Abdomen Pg179

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, who is a cashier in the bank presented to the surgery OPD with complaints of fatigue, vague abdominal discomfort and bloody stools. Colonoscopy revealed a mass in the descending colon. Surgical removal of the mass requires proper ligation of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior Mesenteric Artery

 

Option C: The hindgut structures such as left 1/3 of transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, rectum and upper part of anal canal are supplied by branches of inferior mesenteric arteryInternal iliac artery supplies structures within the pelvis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The coeliac trunk is a major artery that supplies foregut derivatives- stomach, duodenum upto opening of common bile duct, liver, spleen, pancreas. It is not primarily involved in the blood supply to the colon, especially not the descending colon.

 

Option B. The superior mesenteric artery (SMA) supplies midgut derivatives- duodenum distal to the opening of common bile duct, jejunum, ileum, ascending colon, right 2/3 of transverse colon pancreas. While the SMA is a critical artery in gastrointestinal surgery, it is not the primary artery supplying the descending colon.

 

Option D. The internal iliac artery primarily supplies blood to the pelvic organs and the pelvic walls. It is not directly involved in the vascular supply to the descending colon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) supplies blood to the latter parts of the large intestine, including the descending colon, sigmoid colon, and rectum.

  • For a surgical resection of a mass in the descending colon, ligation of the IMA is typically required to properly manage the blood supply to the area of the tumor.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition Pg No. 1088

choices.text: Mcburney's Point is at the Junction of Medial 2/3 and Lateral 1/3 of a line which Extends from the Umbilicus to the Right Anterior Superior Iliac Spine
Inflammation of Appendix Pain is referred to Umbilicus along the Distribution of T9 Segment
In Appendicitis the Pain is often first felt in the Umbilical Region then later in the Right Iliac Area.
Submucosa of Appendix is studded with numerous Lymphoid Follicles

questions.text: A 28-year-old female was brought to ER with complaints of acute pain around the umbilicus, fever and vomiting. On examination the surgeon noted maximum tenderness over McBurney’s point. Which of the following statements pertaining to the above case is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inflammation of Appendix Pain is referred to Umbilicus along the Distribution of T9 Segment

 

Option B:

 

  • Inflammation of appendix pain is referred to the umbilicus along the distribution of the T9 segment: This statement is not true.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. McBurney's point is a clinically significant anatomical landmark located approximately one-third of the way along a line drawn from the umbilicus to the right Anterior Superior Iliac Spine (ASIS). It is commonly used as a reference point for assessing tenderness in cases of suspected appendicitis.

 

 

 

Option C. The sequence of pain progression in appendicitis often starts with periumbilical pain, followed by the migration of pain to the right iliac area as the inflammation worsens. This pattern is characteristic of appendicitis.

 

Option D. The appendix is a lymphoid-rich organ with a high concentration of lymphoid follicles in its submucosa. This feature is a part of its role in the immune system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Appendix Nerve Supply

 

 

 

  • In cases of appendicitis, pain typically begins around the umbilicus (periumbilical) and then migrates to the right lower quadrant of the abdomen, where McBurney's point is located. The referred pain pattern is along the distribution of the T10 segment.

  • In appendicitis the pain is often first felt in the umbilical region then later in the right iliac area due to local peritonitis.

  • Submucosa of appendix is studded with numerous lymphoid follicles; enlargement of these lymph nodes can obstruct blood supply and lead to inflammation of appendix

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition Pg No. 1142

choices.text: The Flexing of the arm with respect to the Forearm around the Elbow.
The Swivelling of the foot to the Medial and Lateral Directions.
The Downward & Upward rotation of Hand when Elbow is Semi Flexed.
The Rotation at the shoulder that causes the arm to describe a Cone Shape.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the movements known as pronation and supination?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The Downward & Upward rotation of Hand when Elbow is Semi Flexed.

 

Option C:

 

  • Supination: Upward rotation of hand in semi flexed elbow (Mid- prone position).
  • Pronation: Downward rotation of hand in semi flexed elbow (Mid- prone position).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The Flexing of the Arm with Respect to the Forearm around the Elbow: This describes flexion and extension, not pronation or supination. Flexion refers to decreasing the angle between the forearm and arm, while extension is increasing this angle.

 

 

Option B. The Swivelling of the Foot to the Medial and Lateral Directions: This is describing inversion and eversion of the foot. Inversion involves turning the sole of the foot inward, while eversion is turning it outward. These movements occur at the ankle and subtalar joints.

 

 

Option D. The Rotation at the Shoulder that Causes the Arm to Describe a Cone Shape: This is describing circumduction, a circular movement of the limb that combines flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction. It is not specific to pronation or supination.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Twisting of the Wrist While the Elbow is Held Motionless: This correctly describes pronation and supination. These movements occur primarily at the radioulnar joint. In pronation, the radius rotates over the ulna so the palm faces downward. In supination, the radius and ulna are parallel, and the palm faces upward.

 

Ref: Textbook of Upper limb and Thorax, 3rd Edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 134

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with anterior knee pain that worsens with activities like running and jumping. On physical examination, there is tenderness and swelling over the front of the knee. Palpation reveals a small, round, bony prominence at the centre of the knee. The patient reports no recent trauma. You will put the involved bone in which of the following type?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sesamoid

 

Option D:

 

  • In this case knee cap bone Patella is involved, which is classical example of sesamoid bone.
  • Important Features of Sesamoid bone.

 

  1. Small and Ossified: Sesamoid bones are typically small, flat, and rounded bones that develop within tendons. They are typically composed of ossified (hardened) tissue.
  2. Location: They are commonly found near joints, especially in areas subject to significant mechanical stress, such as the hands, feet, and knees.
  3. Function: Sesamoid bones serve as pulleys, reducing friction and providing leverage for tendons as they pass over joints. They help improve joint function and protect tendons from excessive wear and tear.
  4. They ossify after the birth.
  5. These bones are having –
    • No Haversian canal.
    • No medullary cavity.
    • No periosteusm.

 

Examples of Sesamoid Bones in Body:

 

  1. Patella (Kneecap):

 

  • The largest sesamoid bone in the human body is the patella, which is located in the front of the knee joint.
  • It is ossified in tendon of quadriceps femoris.

 

  1. Pisiform:

 

  • It ossifies within tendon of flexor carpi ulnaris.
  • It is the last carpal bone to ossify.

 

  1. Fabella:
  • It is found in lateral head of gastrocnemius muscle.

 

  1. At Thumb (First Metacarpal):

 

  • Sesamoid bones are often present at the base of the thumb (first metacarpal bone), where they contribute to the flexibility and strength of thumb movements.

 

  1. At Foot (Metatarsophalangeal Joints):

 

  • Sesamoid bones are commonly found beneath the metatarsophalangeal joints of the foot, especially the first metatarsophalangeal joint near the big toe.
  • They assist in weight-bearing and movement of the foot during activities like walking and running.

 

Clinical Significance:

 

  • Understanding the presence and function of sesamoid bones is essential for healthcare professionals, as injuries or conditions related to these bones can impact joint mobility, stability, and overall musculoskeletal health.
  • X-ray Identification: Sesamoid bones are often visible on X-rays, and their presence and location can be important for diagnosing certain medical conditions, such as fractures or inflammation related to sesamoid bones.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sphenoid –

 

  • It is a complex bone located at the base of the skull, in the middle of the cranial floor.
  • It is not embedded within a tendon.

 

Option B. Hyoid –

 

  • U-shaped bone located in the anterior neck that does not directly articulate with any other bone.
  • It serves as an anchoring structure for the tongue and muscles in the neck and throat but is not embedded within a tendon.

 

Option C. Ethmoid –

 

  • It is located between the eyes and at the roof of the nasal cavity.
  • It is part of the cranial floor and contributes to the medial wall of the orbit, the nasal septum, and the nasal cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sesamoid: Sesamoid bones like patella are small, round bones that are embedded within tendons. They are found in locations where a tendon passes over a joint, such as the knee, hand, and foot. It helps to overcome compressive forces and modify pressure, reduce friction, and occasionally alter the direction of muscle pull.

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 2nd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 69

questions.text: Which of the following bone of the skull articulates to form a synovial joint?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The Mandible

 

Option C:

 

  • The Ramus of the mandible articulates with the temporal bone at the mandibular fossa.
  • The joint is freely moveable, allowing us to chew and speak.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The Sphenoid

 

  • It is a complex bone located at the base of the skull, forming part of the cranial floor.
  • It does not form a synovial joint; rather, it articulates with other cranial bones through sutures.

 

Option B. The Maxilla

 

  • It forms the upper jaw and is involved in forming the roof of the mouth, floors of the orbits, and sides and floor of the nasal cavity.
  • The maxilla is fused to other bones of the face and does not form a synovial joint.

 

Option D. The Hyoid

 

  • It is a U-shaped bone in the neck that supports the tongue and provides attachment for muscles associated with swallowing.
  • It is not directly attached to other bones but is suspended by ligaments and muscles.
  • The hyoid does not form a synovial joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mandible or lower jawbone, forms a synovial joint with the temporal bone of the skull known as the Temporo-Mandibular Joint (TMJ). It is a bicondylar type of synovial joint that allows for the movement necessary for chewing, speaking, and other mouth movements.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy regional and clinical head, 2nd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 17

questions.text: Which of the following lists comprises bones that are part of the appendicular skeleton?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clavicle, Fibula,  Metatarsal, Phalange, Radius

 

Option B.

 

  • Clavicle (Collar bone/ beauty bone) is part of pectoral girdle (Appendicular system)
  • Fibula is postaxial bone of lower limb (Appendicular system)
  • Metatarsal are the bones in the foot, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Phalange are the bones in the hand & foot, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Radius is preaxial bone of forearm (Appendicular system)
  • This list contains bones from appendicular skeletons only, hence it is answer.
  • Skeleton system can be divided into 2 following parts:
    • Axial skeleton
    • Appendicular skeleton
  • All bones of axial & appendicular system are shown in below image

 

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Patella, Ethmoid, Femur, Coccyx, Tibia

 

  • Patella (Kneecap) is part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Ethmoid is a cranial bone, part of the axial skeleton.
  • Femur (Thigh bone) is part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Coccyx (Tailbone) is part of the axial skeleton.
  • Tibia (Shinbone) is part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • This list contains bones from both the axial and appendicular skeletons.

 

Option C. Humerus, Scapula, Occipital, Metacarpal, Sternum

 

  • Humerus (Upper Arm Bone) is part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Scapula (Shoulder Blade) is part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Occipital is a cranial bone, part of the axial skeleton.
  • Metacarpals are the bones in the hand, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Sternum (Breastbone) is part of the axial skeleton.
  • This list contains bones from both the axial and appendicular skeletons.

 

Option D. Ulna, Radius, Phalanges, Mandible, Coxal

 

  • Ulna is a bone in the forearm, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Radius is a bone in the forearm, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Phalanges are the finger and toe bones, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Mandible (Lower Jawbone) is part of the axial skeleton.
  • Coxal (Hip Bone) is part of the pelvic girdle of the appendicular skeleton.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Skeleton system can be divided into 2 following parts:
    • Axial Skeleton
    • Appendicular Skeleton
      • Clavicle (Collar bone/ beauty bone) is part of pectoral girdle (Appendicular System)
      • Fibula is postaxial bone of lower limb (Appendicular System)
      • Metatarsal are the bones in the foot, part of the Appendicular Skeleton.
      • Phalange are the bones in the hand & foot, part of the Appendicular Skeleton.
      • Radius is preaxial bone of forearm (Appendicular System)

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 66

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with complaints of joint pain, swelling, and limited range of motion in the knee joint. Physical examination reveals warmth and tenderness around the affected joint, and imaging studies show joint space narrowing and bone erosion. Which of the following category of joint is most likely associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Freely Moveable Joint

 

Option C.

 

  • Knee joint is the type of diarthosis or synovial joint which is the example of freely moveable joint.
  • Synovial fluid is present in between articular surfaces.
  • In this case knee joint is involved which is classical example of synovial joint.
  • Synovial joints are filled with synovial fluid which is the lubricant that allows friction free joint movement.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Synarthrosis (Fibrous Joint):

 

  • They are a type of joint where the bones are tightly connected and no movement.
  • An example of a synarthrosis is the sutures of the skull.
  • Synarthroses are the opposite of synovial joints, as they allow no movement.

 

Option B. Slightly Movable Joint:

 

  • These joints are also known as amphiarthosis.
  • It allows a small amount of movement, usually because the bones are connected by cartilage.
  • An example is the joints between the vertebrae of the spine.
  • While slightly moveable joints do allow some movement, they do not offer the range of motion seen in synovial joints.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Freely Moveable Joint:

 

  • It allows a wide range of movement. Examples include the knee, hip, shoulder, and elbow.
  • They are characterized by a synovial cavity filled with synovial fluid, which facilitates movement.

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 88

questions.text: In the context of young bones, which part is primarily responsible for longitudinal growth?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Epiphyseal plate

 

It is present between metaphysis and epiphysis in the growing bone. Once the complete fusion of this plate takes place the growth also stops.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Diaphysis

 

  • Part of bone which ossify from primary centre of ossification known as diaphysis.
  • It is the central shaft of a long bone and is not primarily responsible for longitudinal growth.

 

Option B. Epiphysis

 

  • Part of bone which ossify from secondary centre of ossification known as epiphysis.
  • It refers to the ends of the long bone, and while it plays a role in joint function and stability, it is not the primary site for longitudinal growth.

 

Option C. Metaphysis 

 

  • Metaphysis is the part of the bone between diaphysis and growth plate in the growing bone and in the adult bone it lies between diaphysis and epiphysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In young bones, the part primarily responsible for longitudinal growth is the epiphyseal plate (growth plate).

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 74

choices.text: Between the Diaphysis and the Epiphysis

questions.text: Where is the epiphyseal plate of a long bone located?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Between the Diaphysis and the Epiphysis

 

Option B:

 

  • The “Plate” is the Hyaline Cartilage between the Shaft (Diaphysis) and End (Epiphysis) of a Long bone in Children and Adolescents.
  • The plate is responsible for longitudinal growth of the bone, as new bone is added at this location during development.
  • In Adults it is replaced by an ossified “Epiphyseal Line”.

 

 

Explanation

 

Option A. In the Diaphysis: It is the shaft or central part of a long bone. The epiphyseal plate is not located within the diaphysis. Instead, the diaphysis is primarily composed of compact bone and contains the medullary cavity.

 

Option C. In the Epiphysis: The epiphysis refers to the rounded end of a long bone.  While the epiphyseal plate is adjacent to the epiphysis, it is not located within the epiphysis itself. The epiphysis is primarily made of spongy bone and contributes to joint formation.

 

Option D. In the Medullary Canal: The medullary canal, or medullary cavity, is the central cavity of bone shafts where red and yellow bone marrow is stored.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Between the Diaphysis and the Epiphysis: The epiphyseal plate is the area of growing tissue near the ends of the long bones. It is located between the diaphysis and the epiphysis of the bone. The plate is responsible for longitudinal growth of the bone, as new bone is added at this location during development.

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 72

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after falling onto her outstretched hand. She complains of severe pain in her elbow. Physical examination reveals swelling and tenderness over the distal humerus. An X-ray confirms a supracondylar fracture. Upon further examination, the patient is unable to flex her thumb. Which nerve is most likely involved in this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior Interosseous Nerve

 

Option C:

 

  • This is the clinical case of supracondylar fracture of humerus.
  • Median nerve and brachial artery are involved in supracondylar fracture of humerus.

 

 

 

  • Anterior interosseous nerve is deep branch of median nerve.

 

 

  • Supra condylar deformity results in gun stock deformity:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Deep Branch of Ulnar Nerve:

 

  • The deep branch of the ulnar nerve primarily innervates the intrinsic muscles of the hand (excluding the thenar muscles and lateral two lumbricals).
  •  It is involved in the adduction and abduction of fingers, and some aspects of thumb movements, but not primarily responsible for thumb flexion.
  • Injuries to the ulnar nerve typically result in symptoms such as a "claw hand" deformity and sensory loss in the medial side of the hand, not specifically an inability to flex the thumb.

 

Option B. Posterior Interosseous Nerve:

 

  • The posterior interosseous nerve is a branch of the radial nerve.
  • It primarily innervates the extensor muscles of the forearm.
  • Damage to this nerve results in an inability to extend the fingers and the wrist (wrist drop), not an inability to flex the thumb.

 

Option D. Superficial Branch of Ulnar Nerve:

 

  • The superficial branch of the ulnar nerve primarily provides sensory innervation to the medial one and a half fingers and the associated palm area.
  • It does not play a significant role in motor control of the thumb, particularly in flexion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior Interosseous Nerve:

 

  • Anterior interosseous nerve is deep branch of the median nerve, innervates the flexor pollicis longus, the lateral half of the flexor digitorum profundus, and the pronator quadratus.
  •  Injury to this nerve leads to deficits in flexion of the thumb and the distal phalanges of the index and middle fingers, often assessed by the "pinch grip" test where the patient is unable to make an "OK" sign (forming a circle with the thumb and index finger).

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram singh, pg. 165

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a laceration in the anterior region of his elbow following a biking accident. During surgical exploration of the wound, the surgeon notes a structure that has been partially transected. This structure is immediately superficial to a key anatomical structure in the cubital fossa, which the surgeon aims to protect. Which structure is most likely lying underneath the transected tissue?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brachial Artery

 

Option C:

 

  • In this clinical case bicipital aponeurosis is partially transected.
  • Bicipital aponeurosis is the expanded tendon of biceps brachii that inserts into ulna. It lies over the brachial artery.

 

The bicipital aponeurosis is an expansion of the tendon of biceps brachii that extends medially to blend with the deep fascia covering the flexor muscles of the forearm. It lies superficial to the brachial artery (protecting it) and deep to the median cubital vein. This relationship is important clinically because the bicipital aponeurosis separates the median cubital vein (commonly used for venipuncture) from the brachial artery, thereby providing protection to the artery during venipuncture procedures.
 

The contents of the cubital fossa from medial to lateral are:

  1. Median nerve
  2. Brachial artery
  3. Bicipital aponeurosis
  4. Radial nerve (on a deeper plane)
     

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Median Cubital Vein

 

  • It is superficial to the bicipital aponeurosis and is often used for venipuncture.
  • Median cubital vein connects the cephalic and basilic vein.

 

Option B. Radial Nerve:

 

  • The radial nerve does not typically lie directly under the bicipital aponeurosis.
  • Instead, it travels along the radial side of the forearm and is more lateral in the cubital fossa.

 

Option D. Anterior Interosseous Artery:

 

  • This artery is a branch of the ulnar artery and is not covered by the bicipital aponeurosis.
  • It runs on the anterior surface of the interosseous membrane of the forearm and is not located in the cubital fossa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contents of Cubital Fossa - Superficial and deep (With respect to bicipital aponeurosis)
Deep contents (From Medial to Lateral direction)

  1. Median nerve
  2. Brachial artery
  3. Bicipital aponeurosis
  4. Radial nerve (on a deeper plane)
     

 

Cubital Fossa & Brachial Artery:

 

  • The bicipital aponeurosis covers the brachial artery as it courses through the cubital fossa, helping to protect it from compression or injury.

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 101

choices.text: In Colles fracture, the distal fragment shifts posteriorly and downward carrying with it the styloid process
In smith’s fracture the distal fragment is displaced posteriorly and upward

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman sustained a fall on the outstretched hand. She developed pain, tenderness and swelling over the dorsal aspect of her right wrist. She experienced difficulty in performing movements at the wrist. X-ray showed fracture of lower end of lateral bone of forearm. Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) None of the above

 

Option D. None of the above- this is the correct option because both the statements (Option & B) are incorrect.

 

Explanation:

 

The type of dislocation is always ascertained by the displacement of distal fragment and not proximal, i.e., if the distal fragment has displaced anteriorly and proximal fragment has displaced posteriorly - the dislocation will be reffered to as anterior and vice versa.

 

Option A.

 

  • Colles Fracture is defined as the fracture of distal end of radius with dorsal (posterior) displacement of distal fragment along with upwards pulling of distal fragment including the styloid process.
  • This is called dinner fork deformity. Because of this shortening the styloid process of radius and ulna are more or less in line with each other. So, therefore the statement given in Option A is incorrect.

 

Option B.

 

  • Smith’s fracture  is defined as the fracture of distal end of radius with ventral (anterior) displacement of distal fragment including the styloid process.,
  • Smith’s fracture is a fracture of the distal end of the radius and occurs from a fall on the back of hand.
  • It is also called reverse Colles or Garden spade deformity. So, therefore the statement given in the option B is also incorrect.

 

 

Option C. Option C can’t be correct since Both A and B options are incorrect.
Since All the options (A,B,C) are incorrect - None of the above is the correct answer
 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition, pg no. 861

choices.text: The shaft is triangular in the upper half & cylindrical in lower part in cross section
The shaft has 2 borders and three surfaces
Upper third of the lateral border forms the lateral lip of intertubercular sulcus

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with severe pain in his left arm. The patient reports falling off a ladder approximately two hours prior to the presentation. On radiological examination, everything was seen as normal as shown in the image. Which of the following statements is true about the shaft of the pointed structure A in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The shaft has 3 borders & 3 surface

 

Option C:

 

  • The indicated radiological image is showing transverse section of arm & indicated structured marked A is showing the shaft of humerus.
  • The shaft of humerus presents 3 surfaces: Anteromedial, anterolateral & posterior surfaces.

 

 

  • Bony landmarks & attachment of humerus shown in image:

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.

 

  • The proximal or upper half of the humerus shaft does tend to have a more cylindrical cross-section whereas in the lower half, the humerus becomes more triangular.
  • This triangular shape is better suited for the hinge-type joint at the elbow and provides a more uniform surface for muscle attachments and the interlocking of bones at the elbow joint.

 

Option B.

 

  • This statement is not accurate. The shaft of the humerus typically has three borders (anterior, medial, and lateral) and three surfaces (anterolateral, anteromedial, and posterior).
  • These borders and surfaces serve as attachment sites for muscles and provide structural integrity.

 

Option D.

 

  • Intertubercular sulcus is also also known as bicipital groove. The lateral boundary of it is formed by the inferior extension of greater tubercle. 
  • The bicipital groove runs along the proximal end of the humerus and gives attachment to the tendon of the latissimus dorsi.
  • The lateral border runs from the back part of the greater tubercle to the lateral epicondyle, and separates the anterolateral surface from posterior surface.
  • Therefore, option D is incorrect because the lateral lip of the intertubercular sulcus is formed by the greater tubercle, not by the upper third of the lateral border.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The shaft has 3 borders and 3 surfaces.

 

  • 3 Borders: Anterior, Medial, and Lateral.
  • 3 Surfaces: Antero-lateral, Antero-medial, and Posterior.
  • Attachments of bicipital groove
  1. On Medial lip - teres Major
  2. On lateral lip - Pectoralis major
  3. On Floor - latissimus dorsi
  • Tendon of biceps brachii passes via the groove but is not attached with the groove.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy upper limb and thorax, Vishram Singh 3rd edition, pg. 9

choices.text: Loss of Sensation on Lower Lateral Aspect of Arm
Weak of Flexion of Arm at Shoulder Joint
Inability to Extend the Arm at Shoulder Joint

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient was admitted with complaints of acute pain in the right shoulder of three-days duration associated with swelling and he also had difficulty in using his right shoulder since then. Pain was sudden at onset, continuous, and moderate to severe in intensity and it was aggravated on activity. In addition, he had severe night and rest pain. He also gave a history of intramuscular injection of Iron in the right deltoid region 2 weeks previously, which was administered in a local clinic. On examination, there was a globular swelling in the lateral aspect of the right arm extending up to the scapular region. There was a local rise of temperature and tenderness over the swelling, painful restriction of the right shoulder movements and he could not abduct his arm to the right angle. MRI scan of the right shoulder showed pyomyositis of the posterior belly of the right deltoid muscle with central abscess formation. Which among the following is not a possible complication that can be expected in this case if untreated?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of Sensation on Lower Lateral Aspect of Arm

 

Option A:

 

  • The case describes a patient with pyomyositis of the deltoid muscle, which is a bacterial infection leading to abscess formation within the muscle.
  • In this case, the intramuscular injection injured the axillary nerve supply to the deltoid muscle.
  • Axillary nerve gives rise to upper lateral cutaneous nerve of arm, supplies deltoid & teres minor.
  • Damage to this nerve results in loss of sensation at upper lateral part of arm known as “ Regimental badge anaesthesia”

 

 

  • In A option Loss of sensation on lower lateral aspect of arm is mentioned which is wrong.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B.

 

  • Abduction of the shoulder:

 

 

  • Pyomyositis in the deltoid muscle would primarily affect the function of the deltoid, which is responsible for abduction.

 

Option C.

 

  • The deltoid muscle, particularly its anterior fibers, plays a role in flexing the arm at the shoulder.
  • Pyomyositis affecting the deltoid muscle could feasibly lead to weakness in flexing the arm at the shoulder joint, as the compromised muscle may lose strength and functionality.

 

Option D.

 

  • The primary muscles for extending the arm at the shoulder are the posterior deltoid, latissimus dorsi, and teres major.
  • Since the posterior belly of the deltoid muscle is involved in this case, it could lead to an inability or weakness in extending the arm at the shoulder joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sensation in the lower lateral aspect of the arm is generally mediated by the cutaneous nerves, which is branch of radial nerve.
